title: Terry McLean
text:
Sir Terence Power McLean (15 July 1913 – 11 July 2004) was a New Zealand sports journalist and author specialising in <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a>.
Early life and family.
McLean was born in <a href="Whanganui">Wanganui</a> and died in <a href="Auckland">Auckland</a>. He was educated at <a href="New%20Plymouth%20Boys%27%20High%20School">New Plymouth Boys' High School</a>. He married Margaret Coyle in 1940; they had one son and two daughters.
He came from a rugby family, and several other McLeans were notable in the New Zealand rugby union, including <a href="Hubert%20McLean">Hubert McLean</a> who was an <a href="All%20Black">All Black</a> in the 1930s. His father and four uncles played for Wanganui, and his brothers Gordon (Taranaki) and Bob (Wellington) played at the provincial level.
Career.
McLean commenced as a journalist on the "<a href="Auckland%20Sun">Auckland Sun</a>" in 1930, subsequently working on the "<a href="Hastings%20Tribune">Hastings Tribune</a>", "New Zealand Observer", "<a href="Taranaki%20Daily%20News">Taranaki Daily News</a>," and "<a href="The%20Evening%20Post%20%28New%20Zealand%29">Evening Post</a>" (Wellington). After service in <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>, he joined the "<a href="The%20New%20Zealand%20Herald">New Zealand Herald</a>" in <a href="Auckland">Auckland</a> as sports editor in 1946.
For the next 30 years, McLean accompanied most <a href="New%20Zealand%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">All Black teams</a> overseas and visiting sides in New Zealand, writing a series of tour books and other books on rugby, 32 in total. He retired from the "Herald" in 1978.
Honours and awards.
In the <a href="1978%20Birthday%20Honours%20%28New%20Zealand%29">1978 Queen's Birthday Honours</a>, McLean was appointed a <a href="Member%20of%20the%20Order%20of%20the%20British%20Empire">Member of the Order of the British Empire</a>, for services to sporting journalism. In the <a href="1997%20New%20Year%20Honours%20%28New%20Zealand%29">New Year Honours 1997</a>, McLean was appointed a <a href="Knight%20Companion%20of%20The%20New%20Zealand%20Order%20of%20Merit">Knight Companion of The New Zealand Order of Merit</a>, also for services to sporting journalism. He was inducted into the <a href="International%20Rugby%20Hall%20of%20Fame">International Rugby Hall of Fame</a> in 2007.
